metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Heihe remote sensing station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Heihe remote sensing station from January 1 to December 31, 2023. The site (100.4756° E, 38.8270° N) was located on artificial grassland in Dangzhai Town of Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1560 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (1.5 m, north), wind speed and direction (10 m, north), air pressure (2 m), rain gauge (0.7 m), four-component radiometer (1.5 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (1.5 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6 m), and two photosynthetically active radiation (1.5 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1.5, RH_1.5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm) (℃),on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2023-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is an oasis–desert system in the context of arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: An oasis–desert system in arid and semiarid regions refers to a unique ecological landscape where oases, which comprise less than 10% of the total area, support more than 90% of the population in these regions. This system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity, especially in western China.

Definition.Question: What is the importance of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for achieving sustainable oasis development, supporting ecological security, and maintaining socioeconomic development. These studies are significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, supporting the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, and protecting the ecological stability.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Definition.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges like ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in regions along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the ecological balance in oasis–desert systems from the long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets collected in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The datasets from oasis–desert systems provide insights into the balance between these ecosystems, which is critical for sustainable oasis development. By understanding the exchange of energy, water vapor, and carbon, researchers can assess the interactions within these systems, which is significant for protecting ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection methods, such as the use of eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, contribute to understanding the carbon balance in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations helps acquire precise measurements of turbulent fluxes and hydrometeorological data, which are essential for understanding the carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. These methods allow for detailed observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, facilitating a quantitative understanding of the carbon balance in these regions.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges might arise in maintaining data quality and consistency for long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems, and how are these addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality for long-term observations include dealing with missing data, repeated records, and data that exceed physical or instrumental limits. These are addressed through rigorous data processing and quality control measures, such as marking missing data, removing duplicates, and identifying questionable data, to ensure the reliability and consistency of the datasets.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure the quality and reliability of data collected from meteorological stations in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures involve ensuring a consistent data collection rate, specifically collecting 144 data points per day at 10-minute intervals. Missing data are marked with a specific placeholder (-6999), duplicate records are removed, and any data points that fall outside of the instrument's physical range are deleted. Questionable data are highlighted in red, and date and time formats are standardized.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to integrate multiple types of environmental data to assess ecosystem interactions in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data. These are acquired through an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations. The integration involves collecting data on radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, air and soil moisture, precipitation, and additional vegetation and soil parameters.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies enable the comprehensive monitoring of meteorological elements in arid and semiarid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Observational technologies such as automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and scintillometers enable the comprehensive monitoring of meteorological elements. These technologies facilitate the observation of variables including air temperature, humidity, wind speed, direction, and soil parameters. They are crucial for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert systems.

The 黑河流域地表过程综合观测网 dataset addresses these challenges by marking missing data, excluding duplicates, and flagging dubious records.
